---
title: "Upterm Installation and Setup Guide"
format: html
---

This guide walks through installing and setting up `upterm` on macOS with Apple
Silicon (M1-M5 chip).  This allows you to share your terminal session with
others. They will be able to type into it just like you can even they are
remote. You should use this during Google Meet and you want to share terminal
sessions. So for example you can share a Claude Code session with more than one
person.

## Installation Commands

Copy and paste the commands below and give them to Claude Code. Ask Claude to make a script called `upterm.sh` for this that you can execute.

These commands install upterm on your machine.


```bash
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -f ~/.ssh/id_ed25519 -N ""
mkdir upterm
cd upterm
curl -L https://github.com/owenthereal/upterm/releases/latest/download/upterm_darwin_arm64.tar.gz -o upterm.tar.gz
tar -xzf upterm.tar.gz
sudo mkdir -p /usr/local/bin
sudo mv upterm /usr/local/bin/
sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/upterm
cd ..
rm -rf upterm
upterm version
```

Exit Claude Code with /exit and execute the script like this at the terminal prompt: 

```bash
./update.sh
```

When it asks for your Password type in the password for your mac. It will look like it is not letting you type but it actually is. Then hit return.

If you get output like this then it worked:
 
```bash
Upterm version 0.20.0
Git commit: 316bea9df1fc33ed3ce7e8e8ff1afa220ba0ec2e
Build date: 2025-12-02T03:48:51Z
```

## Start Upterm Host Session

Next we can start up a server that can be shared with others

### Option 1: Default Server

Try this first:

```bash
upterm host --accept
```

Example output:

If it works it will look something like this:

```bash
$ upterm host --accept
╭─ Session: tx065Om9KTrCxPZZ8fWQ ─╮
┌──────────────────┬─────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ Command:         │ /bin/zsh                                    │
│ Force Command:   │ n/a                                         │
│ Host:            │ ssh://uptermd.upterm.dev:22                 │
│ Authorized Keys: │ n/a                                         │
│                  │                                             │
│ ➤ SSH Command:   │ ssh tx065Om9KTrCxPZZ8fWQ@uptermd.upterm.dev │
└──────────────────┴─────────────────────────────────────────────┘

╰─ Run 'upterm session current' to display this again ─╯

✅ Starting to accept connections...
```

Copy and paste the SSH Command (here it is `ssh tx065Om9KTrCxPZZ8fWQ@uptermd.upterm.dev` but yours will be different) to share your terminal session with others. Paste just that into the google meet chat.

If that doesnt work then we will try Options 2 and 3 below. Sometimes the port 22 is blocked. But the options below might work.

### Option 2: Using uptermd.upterm.dev

```bash
upterm host --server wss://uptermd.upterm.dev --accept
```

Example output:

If this works it looks something like this:

```bash
$ upterm host --server wss://uptermd.upterm.dev --accept

ED25519 key fingerprint is SHA256:9ajV8JqMe6jJE/s3TYjb/9xw7T0pfJ2+gADiBIJWDPE.
Are you sure you want to continue connecting (yes/no/[fingerprint])? yes
╭─ Session: aDdSuXNrnol4fMIN4VYf ─╮
┌──────────────────┬──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ Command:         │ /bin/zsh                                                                                                                     │
│ Force Command:   │ n/a                                                                                                                          │
│ Host:            │ wss://uptermd.upterm.dev                                                                                                     │
```

Here you copy and paste the long ssh command (here it is `ssh -o ProxyCommand=...` all the way and including the ending  `:433`. 

Yours will be different but include all of it and send it to whoever you want to connect to your terminal.

### Option 3: Using upterm.dev

If neither of the above works, try this below:

```bash
upterm host --server wss://upterm.dev --accept
```
